  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation 







Hi, everyone, 
Tens of thousands draped themselves in Iraqi flags 
      and marched through the streets of two Shiite holy cities today to mark 
      the fourth anniversary of Baghdad's fall  to 
      U.S. troops. The show of 
      force was orchestrated by the radical Shiite cleric Moqtada al Sadr, who 
      proved that he commands an enormous following among Iraq's largest 
      religious group. Martin Seemungal is 
      in Baghdad, and will have more on this story tonight. 
Iran announced a dramatic expansion of uranium enrichment, saying 
      it has begun operating 3,000 centrifuges. That's nearly 10 times the 
      previously known number, and is in defiance of U.N. demands that it halt the program or face increased 
      sanctions. We will have a reality check on the real threat from 
      Iran. 
President Bush is making another push for 
      immigration reform. He visited the U.S.-Mexico border to tout a guest 
      worker program for immigrants. With up to 12 million illegal immigrants in 
      the U.S., lawmakers haven't agreed on how to uphold the law without 
      disrupting lives, eroding the work force and risking political upheaval. 
      Kelly Cobiella will report from the 
      desert stretch where Arizona and Mexico meet. 
      Border agents there say they are pelted with rocks and the victims of 
      assault from smugglers. In fact, there have been more assaults against 
      agents in the Yuma sector this year than all of last year.  
At any one time in this country, as many as 100,000 
      people are suffering from heart failure, but only about 2,000 people a 
      year receive heart transplants. For a long time, doctors were focused on 
      developing a heart pump as a bridge to when a new heart becomes 
      available.  But a new device is showing it can be more than just a 
      bridge. Our contributing medical correspondent, CNN's Sanjay Gupta, will 
      tell you about this. 
There's also a growing uproar over 
      radio host Don Imus' racially charged comments about the Rutgers 
      University women's basketball team.  Despite his 
      on-air apologies, the calls continue for him to be fired from his 
      syndicated morning program, after his racially charged comments. Imus 
      appeared on the Rev. Al Sharpton's radio program today and issued another 
      apology. Richard Schlesinger will have this report, and 
      will discuss the FCC's regulations as well.  
Finally, for computer researcher Zombie Bell even 
      his morning walk to work is part of a grand experiment in digitizing and 
      remembering everything. The little camera around his neck takes a picture 
      every 30 seconds or so, and a sound recorder rolls non-stop. Bell is 
      saving his whole life on computer, from childhood certificates to all his 
      medical records. John Blackstone will have his story.
 I hope 
      to see you tonight.

Katie CouricCouricandCo@cbs.com
